Context:
The George Brown College offers a three-year Business Administration – Marketing program. This program is accredited by the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP), making it one of only two colleges in Ontario to have earned this recognition. Students can participate in various extracurricular activities, including the Ontario Colleges Marketing Competition, Vanier BDC Case Challenge, Enactus George Brown, Speed mentoring event, Great Canadian Sales Competition, and Ad Week. Students also have the opportunity to earn a business elective credit through the Field Education Course (BUS 1067) or apply for the program with work experience by applying to B158.

George Brown marketing students have access to membership in two Canadian marketing associations: the Canadian Marketing Association (CMA) and the Interactive Advertising Bureau (IAB). CMA membership includes live and online events, professional development opportunities, tools, resources, and guides for members only, networking opportunities with thousands of marketers, and access to CMA NXT. IAB membership offers student volunteer opportunities for marquee events, members-only webinars and podcasts, original Canadian digital marketing research, globally accepted digital ad standards, and globally standardized courses, certification, and custom workshops.

Graduates from the Business Administration – Marketing program are prepared for careers in various business sectors.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Business Administration – Marketing Program B108 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Business Administration – Marketing program at the college prepares students for careers in various business sectors such as advertising agencies, marketing consulting firms, telecommunication and media, digital marketing, retailers, financial institutions, government, not-for-profit, and small businesses. Graduates from this program have secured jobs as marketing coordinator, account executive, product manager, social media coordinator, digital marketing manager, medical planner or media buyer, market researcher, event marketer, sales account manager, and small business owner.

Students who complete the program can further their studies by enrolling in additional marketing programs at George Brown College. These include the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Digital Marketing) Program B312, Sport and Event Marketing Program (Postgraduate) B400, Marketing Management – Financial Services Program (Postgraduate) B406, Strategic Relationship Marketing Program (Postgraduate) B409, and Marketing Management – Digital Media Program (Postgraduate) B433.

To graduate from the program, students must complete a total of 37 courses: 30 mandatory courses, 4 business electives, and 3 general education electives. Depending on their placement test results, students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) or MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation) before progressing to other courses, but these do not count towards the 38 courses required for graduation and will incur additional charges. Students are required to make up any failed or dropped courses before they can graduate. General education courses must be chosen from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI). Students are responsible for making up any failed or dropped courses.

Required Courses:
- 30 mandatory courses
- 4 business electives
- 3 general education electives

Additional Marketing Programs at George Brown College:
- Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Digital Marketing) Program B312
- Sport and Event Marketing Program (Postgraduate) B400
- Marketing Management – Financial Services Program (Postgraduate) B406
- Strategic Relationship Marketing Program (Postgraduate) B409
- Marketing Management – Digital Media Program (Postgraduate) B433

PROGRAM LEARNING OUTCOMES:
- Develop a marketing plan that will meet the needs or goals of a business or organization.
- Develop an integrated marketing communication plan for marketing of a product, concept, good or service based on an identified market need or target.
- Determine strategies for the development of new and/or modified marketing concepts, products, goods and services.

Context:
The text provides information on various marketing strategies and skills that can be learned in a program offered by the college. It also includes details about tuition fees for domestic and international students, financial assistance options, and a disclaimer. Here's the extracted information:

- Marketing strategies: Determining strategies for new/modified marketing concepts, product placement/distribution, analyzing market viability, conducting market research, communicating marketing information, sales presentation, maintaining working relationships, entrepreneurial strategies, organizational policies and practices, business ethics and corporate social responsibility.
- Tuition fees:
  - Domestic students: $3,798.00 for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023.
  - International students: $17,925.00 for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2024.
- Financial assistance: The program is approved for OSAP funding for eligible applicants.
- Disclaimer: Fees are subject to change without notice and do not include books, which are to be purchased separately. International students should visit the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.

Context:
* This program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet OSAP eligibility criteria.
* Disclaimer: Information on the website is subject to change without notice.
* Applicants are selected based on academic achievement and may need to take the Admissions Assessment or upgrade their English and Math skills.
* Required high school courses: Ontario Secondary School Diploma, grade 12 English (C or U), and grade 11 Math (C, M or U) or grade 12 (C or U).
* Mature students (aged 19 or older) may also apply.
* Some college and university credits may be eligible for exemptions; check the transfer guide for details.
* English language proficiency is necessary for success in the program; review the English proficiency requirements.
* International students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should use the George Brown College Online Application System.
* Contact information for domestic and international student admissions is provided in the text.
* Information sessions are held regularly; sign up for an upcoming session.

Context: For international students seeking advice on programs and which program might be best suited for them, they can make an appointment to see an Entry Advisor. The Centre for Business offers programs out of the School of Marketing, with classes taking place at the St. James Campus, mainly at 200 King St. E. and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Interested individuals can contact international recruitment representatives by country of origin for more information or book a virtual meeting on the International Contact Us page. Financial inquiries should be directed to the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section. For program-specific inquiries related to the Business Administration Marketing (B108/158) program, individuals can contact Lori Futterer, Program Co-ordinator, at lfuttere@georgebrown.ca or John Peco, Chair, School of Marketing, at john.peco@georgebrown.ca. Campus tours and info sessions are offered regularly, and interested individuals can sign up on the website. The Centre for Business can be followed on Instagram and LinkedIn.
